speaker: Bernie Sanders
vclaim: "Every other major country" has paid family leave.
date: stated on October 14, 2015 in the CNN Democratic presidential debate in Las Vegas:
title: Bernie Sanders says "Every other major country" has paid family leave except the United States.
text: Bernie Sanders defended his record as a democratic socialist by calling on the United States to bring its family leave policy into line with other countries. "You see every other major country telling mothers that, when you have a child, we're not gonna separate you from your newborn child, because we're gonna have paid medical leave and family, like every other country on Earth," said during the first democratic presidential debate. We will set aside the narrower issue of medical leave and focus on family leave. A speaker on behalf of Sanders referred to data from the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), which examined paid maternity leave for some 34 OECD countries - developed countries - and seven additional European Union countries. On average, mothers in all OECD countries are entitled to 17 weeks of paid maternity leave. However, the United States is the only country that does not provide any legal entitlement to paid leave on a national basis. Another widely respected source of data on this subject is the International Labour Organization (ILO), a United Nations agency. In 2014, out of 170 countries, all but two provided cash benefits to women during maternity leave: the United States and Papua New Guinea. In the United States, under the Federal Family Medical Leave Act, employers with 50 or more employees must allow parents an annual leave of 12 weeks of protected work to care for newborns or a family member with a serious health condition. While the Act protects their functions, in most cases leave is unpaid. Some employers choose to take paid leave. Some 13 per cent of workers received some type of paid family leave in 2014, according to the Office of Labour Statistics. This is a very low rate compared to the rest of the developed world. Of the 41 other advanced economies, the United States also imposes the shortest period of unpaid leave - 12 weeks. In the meantime, both the United Kingdom and Australia allow a full year of leave (though not all are paid). However, some countries exclude certain categories of workers, such as those in temporary or part-time employment or working on farms, as domestic servants, police, armed forces or civil servants. In some cases, such as domestic workers, laws do not explicitly clarify whether or not leave policies apply, while the explicit legal exclusion of agricultural workers has been identified in at least 27 countries. ILO recommends that countries provide these benefits: women should receive at least 14 weeks of leave; they should be paid at least two thirds of their previous income; and the State should pay the benefit almost entirely through public funds or social security. The United States is the only developed country that does not meet any of the criteria. "The absence of paid leave, paid leave and national health insurance reflects a long history of a business-dominated political economy," said Ruth Milkman, a sociologist at New York City University. There has been little legislative action to change this policy here. In March, Ms. Christine Gilbert, from D-NY, introduced the Family Leave and Medical Insurance Act to allow 60 eligible days of care per year, but she did not get a vote. Sanders is one of 19 sponsors, all democratic. (Sanders is independent in the Senate but running for president as a democracy.) Our sentence (Sanders) said "every other major country" has paid family leave. Two comprehensive studies of Sanders ' multi-state opinion support the fact that the United States is an extraordinary country when it comes to paid family leave. One study concluded that the United States was the only country that did not provide any legal entitlement to paid leave on a national basis. A separate study of a larger number of countries found that only the United States and Papua New Guinea did not provide cash benefits to women during maternity leave.
